nodes.text:
A “NON-LOCAL COMPLIANCE NOTICE” hangs in a clear sleeve like it’s meant to be ignored.
The barcode isn’t any local format you’ve ever seen.

Under the bland header, the phrasing is… not municipal.
It reads like a queue talking to a node.

choices.text: (look) Read the notice line by line.

nodes.text:
You skim. It’s all holds and references and the word “pending” doing too much work.
It still feels like somebody else’s problem—until you remember: you’re the endpoint.
The barcode keeps sitting there, patient as a docket number.

NOTICE — NON-LOCAL COMPLIANCE CONDITION.
SUBJECT NODE: SOL‑EARTH‑LOCAL.
ACTION: HOLD STATE PENDING DOCUMENTATION.
MANAGING AUTHORITY: METASTABLE TRANSFER AUTHORITY (MTA).
REFERENCE: [a long, segmented reference string].
Someone has underlined “HOLD STATE” twice, like that will make it negotiable.

No signature. No local stamp.
Just routing marks in pencil: copied, posted, re-posted.

The barcode has check digits and section breaks like a shipping label—except the fields are jurisdictional, not geographic.
You’ve seen this structure before. Not in OLEA. Upstream.
This is MTA.

Saying it out loud makes the rest of the room rearrange itself.
The “generic” notices aren’t generic. They’re translations. Bad ones.

choices.text: (look) Re-read the notice for reference fields.
(use) Extract variance language from the misfit templates.

nodes.text:
Same sentence bones. Same obsession with standing. Same “processing window active” cadence.
Different local headers pasted on top like name tags at a conference.

The rack is full of templates that almost match local forms, but not quite.
Margins tuned for different scanners. Section titles that don’t correspond to any city department.

One template uses the same reference-string pattern as the notice—down to the punctuation.
It’s labeled, in small print: TEMPORARY OPERATING VARIANCE (LIMITED‑PURPOSE).
You can take it now, or keep confirming what it’s for.

The envelopes are pre-addressed with local destinations—city offices, contractor P.O. boxes—
but the return block is a blank rectangle where an authority mark should be.

Inside the flap, there’s a routing code printed in tiny type.
It matches the notice barcode’s field breaks. Not local mail. Forwarded, then disguised.
Which means the “non-local” part wasn’t a metaphor. It was the sender.

The reference string isn’t random. It’s structured: authority, category, queue, and a time marker pretending it’s not time.
There’s even a slot for “reason phrase,” left blank like a dare.
The room isn’t a warning board. It’s a filing system for an argument you haven’t made yet.

You select the template that matches the notice’s grammar—the one that treats existence as a credential.
The variance section is written to satisfy a hold without admitting fault.

A category line is preformatted in a way local paperwork never would be:
RETIREMENT PROCESSING — LIMITED‑PURPOSE LICENSED RELATIONSHIP — MUNICIPAL LEGACY INFRASTRUCTURE.
It reads like someone trying not to say “this is normal.”

You select the template that matches the notice’s grammar—the one that treats existence as a credential.
The variance section is written to satisfy a hold without admitting fault.

The category field is present, but the acceptable values are footnoted in a separate appendix you don’t have.
A handwritten sticky note is attached: “DO NOT INVENT A CATEGORY. IT COMES BACK.”
